title: Australia's first treaty with Aboriginal people signed in Victoria | ABC NEWS
description: Australia's first treaty with Aboriginal people has been signed and formalised as law. It follows nearly a decade of consultation and negotiation between the Victorian government and Indigenous leaders. The treaty has been applauded internationally by the United Nations. title: Hopes of a rate cut pushed well into 2026 after better than expected jobs report | The Business
description: A better than expected jobs report has pushed hopes of a rate cut well in to next year. The unemployment rate fell to 4.3 per cent in October, undercutting RBA and market forecasts. While the official jobless rate may be relatively low, it seems to be getting harder for those hitting the pavement in search of work. More than 40,000 jobs were added with many of them seasonal casuals.  Highly skilled job seeker Simon Torok says he's applied for more than 300 jobs in the last six months with just seven interviews.  Senior economist for online jobs site Seek says he's seeing record high numbers of applications. The strong jobs numbers puts the Reserve Bank under pressure as borrowers clamour for rate relief. #ABCBusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: 2025 rate cuts unlikely, DroneShield plunges after CEO dumps shares | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: The Reserve Bank is unlikely to cut interest rates again in the near future after the ABS released better-than-expected job figures, which showed the unemployment rate falling to 4.3%.  The reduced odds of a rate cut led to a bad day for the ASX 200 , while DroneShield's share price plunged more than 30% after its CEO sold all his shares in the company for $49.5 million. title: Aussies waiting years for public specialist appointments | ABC NEWS
description: Some Australians are waiting more than six years to see specialists like neurologists in parts of the country. Doctors are warning people are suffering irreversible compllications, and even risk dying while they languish on public waiting lists. title: Newly released Epstein emails allege Trump 'knew about the girls' | ABC NEWS
description: Questions are again swirling about what Donald Trump knew about Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of young girls after US lawmakers released a series of emails. House Democrats released three email exchanges involving the late convicted paedophile, prompting House Republicans to release thousands more.  The developments came as Congress reconvened to vote on legislation to end the government shutdown. title: Dumping net zero will spook investors says economist, Orica says it's disruptive | The Business
description: The Liberal Party has announced it will scrap its net zero by 2050 commitment as part of its energy and climate policy. Opposition Leader Susan Ley says the party can deliver lower power prices and reduced emissions without the target. The announcement has been met with silence and in some cases, open dismay. Businesses say when it comes to Australia's climate commitments, they've been consistent in asking for policy certainty. Director of Green Energy Markets Tristan Edis says the announcement would make some international investors nervous. "Before this announcement I think investors could at least reassure themselves that if they make the investments, they can at least say, 'you've made a promise you need to deliver on it'", he says. "But now I think there would be a great degree of nervousness about that". Orica CEO Sanjeev Gandhi says the change is disruptive and "we do not want to end up decimating manufacturing in Australia." #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: Liberal Party scraps its commitment to net zero emissions by 2050 | ABC NEWS
description: The Liberal Party has officially dumped its commitment to net zero, marking a u-turn for the party. It's also a break in bipartisanship on the long term climate target. Sussan Ley has instead put energy affordability in focus, offering a guarantee that power prices will be lower under a Coalition government. National Affairs Correspondent Jane Norman reports. title: Report reveals concerns about restraint methods in SA youth detention centre | ABC NEWS
description: Children and young people at Adelaide's only youth detention centre are being forced into a restraint position by staff at the facility, according to a report tabled in parliament. The report found the restraint techniques being used were risky and "may constitute a breach of human rights and clinical best practice". The South Australian state government says it will continue engaging with stakeholders to work through the recommendations made in the report. title: Up to 20 Yipirinya School staff facing job losses amid 'shock' redundancies in NT | ABC NEWS
description: The future of an independent Indigenous school in Alice Springs is under a cloud, as it faces plummeting enrolments, debts climbing into the millions and sweeping layoffs  But teachers and staff members warn the job cuts will jeopardise the future of the school and its students. Roxanne Fitzgerald has this report, followed by an analysis from Olivana Lathouris in the studio for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Japanese village struggles to drive away macaques from residential areas | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Among Japan's many tourist draws hundreds of macaque monkeys roaming through its northern alps remain very popular. Locals, however, see them as pests. Despite huge efforts to drive the animals out of residential areas, there are growing calls to cull them. title: Why New Zealanders are leaving in record numbers and moving to Australia | The World | ABC News
description: New migration data shows a record number of people are leaving new Zealand, and most are choosing to move to Australia. It's prompted fears of a brain drain, as workers look for opportunities they say aren't available at home.
